intro: Astragalus albescens, commonly known as the white milkvetch, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender stems and small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant has compound leaves with numerous leaflets and produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. It is adapted to drought conditions and often grows in sandy or rocky soils, making it a hardy species in harsh environments. Astragalus albescens plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity in its native habitats.
